title: Modifying Duties Addressing the Synthetic Opioid Supply Chain in the People's Republic of China

enrichment.summary: This executive order reduces the additional tariff rate on certain products from China related to synthetic opioids from 20% back to 10% starting November 10, 2025, in response to China’s commitment to stop the flow of fentanyl and related chemicals to the United States. The order tasks the Secretary of Homeland Security and other officials with monitoring China’s compliance and allows adjustments if China fails to meet its commitments.
potential_concerns: Reducing tariffs on synthetic opioid-related products from China may weaken leverage on China to fully comply, potentially prolonging the opioid crisis affecting American communities and increasing burdens on law enforcement officers at federal and state levels.

Lower tariffs might lead to increased importation volumes, unintentionally increasing the availability of fentanyl precursors that can contribute to addiction and overdose risks among middle-class Americans and manufacturing workers producing related chemicals.

Large corporations importing affected products may benefit from reduced costs but could face reputational risks if the order is seen as prioritizing trade interests over public health, potentially causing public criticism.
Consumers may face indirect risks if fentanyl and synthetic opioids continue to circulate in the illicit market due to insufficient enforcement or compliance monitoring.
